notes: Third generation performance coupe on GM G-platform (RWD). Famous for turbocharged variants: T-Type, Grand National (all-black), limited-edition GNX (1987, 547 units). 3.8L V6 with various turbo configurations. RWD only. Grand National/GNX are highly collectible performance vehicles. Difficulty modifier 1.1 reflects turbocharged performance systems requiring specialized service. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Regal / Buick Grand National articles, December 19, 2024 revision.

Sixth generation full-size sedan, downsized and converted to FWD on GM C-platform. 3.0L V6 initially, 3.8L V6 standard by 1986. Replaced by Park Avenue for 1991. Standard service complexity for 1980s full-size FWD sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Electra article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Seventh generation full-size sedan, downsized and converted to FWD on GM H-platform. 3.0L V6 initially, 3.8L V6 by 1986. Coupe variant offered 1987-1991. Transitioned to eighth generation (1992) on same platform. Standard service complexity for 1980s full-size FWD sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick LeSabre article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Fifth generation compact sedan/coupe on GM N-platform shared with Pontiac Grand Am, Oldsmobile Calais. Multiple engine options including high-performance Quad 4 inline-4. FWD only. Somerset nameplate used 1985-1987, renamed Skylark 1987+. Standard service complexity for 1980s compact FWD sedan. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Skylark article, December 19, 2024 revision.

Two-seat personal luxury coupe/convertible hand-assembled at Lansing Craft Centre. GM E-platform (shortened). 3.8L V6 with 4-speed automatic. FWD only. Coupe 1988-1989, convertible 1990-1991. Low production numbers (21,751 total). Touchscreen CRT interface (innovative for 1988). Discontinued after 1991 model year. Standard service complexity for 1980s-1990s personal luxury vehicle. Data sourced from Wikipedia Buick Reatta article, December 19, 2024 revision.
